definition:
Let $E$ be a topological space on which a topological group $G$ acts
continuously and freely. The map $\pi:E\to E/G=B$ is called a *principal
bundle* (or *principal $G$-bundle*) if the projection map $\pi:E\to B$
is a locally trivial bundle.

Any principal bundle with a section $\sigma:B\to E$ is trivial, since
the map $\phi:B\times G\to E$ given by $\phi(b,g)=g\cdot\sigma(b)$ is an
isomorphism. In particular, any $G$-bundle which is topologically
trivial is also isomorphic to $B\times G$ as a $G$-space. Thus any local
trivialization of $\pi:E\to B$ as a topological bundle is an equivariant
trivialization.
